Award.AwardTitle: PROMISE: Providing Resources and Opportunities to Maximize Interest in STEM Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The PROMISE project is a campus-wide effort that encourages new freshmen and sophomore students to select STEM as a career choice. It is comprehensively targeting several populations of students at risk of not being recruited or retained in STEM majors including students from underrepresented groups, undecided and STEM freshmen and sophomore students, and economically, culturally, socially, and educationally disadvantaged students. PROMISE is developing five key components to increase retention and graduation rates: 1) a summer pre-college program; 2) academic support structures in STEM courses; 3) research and peer opportunities with faculty and students; 4) career, job readiness and/or graduate school preparation for STEM majors and; 5) faculty development opportunities that integrate best practices in STEM. The project is utilizing strong institutional student support services already in place, and is also developing a number of new intervention strategies that are designed to increase first and second-year retention rates of targeted students, establish STEM learning communities in academic and residential settings, and expand the opportunities for targeted students to engage in interdisciplinary research with faculty mentors. By recruiting undecided students to major in a STEM discipline and by increasing the first and second year retention rates by at least 20%, the PROMISE project expects to be producing an additional 80 U.S. citizens who are completing STEM baccalaureate degrees annually by the end of the project period.

POR.DRECONTENT:
High Impact #1:  Common Intellectual Experiences

 

Seminars.

IT/STEM Fair

On September 20, 2017 Career Services hosted an IT/STEM Recruiting Fair. Nine Scholars attended the event and rated the event excellent.  The event focused on “meet the firm”.  Students participated in one-on-one professional exchanges with IT and STEM employers. 

Career Fair, Internship, Engineering, Health Professionals Prep Job Fair/Workshop

 

During the Fall and Spring semesters, PROMISE Scholars attended a series of career, intern and job fair preparation workshops. Beginning in 2016, the first graduating class of Scholars received their STEM diplomas. Since that year, many Scholars expressed interest in pursuing career jobs or related career experiences. During the Fall 2017 and Spring 2018, a total of 42 PROMISE Scholars attended NIU’s career preparation fairs over the academic year.  The career preparation services focused on:  how to meet and greet employers, internships and jobs, how to research, prepare, interview, appropriate dining etiquette, and information about employment in majors.  They reviewed the top skills employers seek, how to set personal goals for what they wanted to achieve at the event, listed the top 10 employers they wanted to visit as well as a practice session employer, researched the companies of interest, and matched their skill sets to that required by the employer.

 

Career Dining Etiquette 101

On March 8, 2018 PROMISE Scholars participated in a Dining Etiquette 101 sponsored by NIU’s Career Services Department.  This was the first time for an etiquette engagement activity.  The focus of this activity centered on assisting students in learning proper table manners for formal dining in preparation for internships and full-time employment. O

 

Advising and Student Support.

All PROMISE Scholars are required to meet with the academic advisor of their major or college. PROMISE staff is in contact with these advisors.

 

PROMISE staff actively monitor the progress of the Scholars. At the initial September meeting, the PROMISE staff and/or Academic Advisors complete a form recording the Scholar’s schedule, potential grades, and relevant comments about academic coursework and progress. The staff person rates the Scholar’s personal/social progress as OK (well adjusted), Needs Improvement, or Needs Immediate Attention for 1) work/school balance, 2) time management, 3) use of resources such as study groups, tutoring, office hours, etc.), and 4) resident hall/roommates. Interests in student organizations are listed on the form. Follow-up issues are written in a special section on the form.

 

Financial Aid

On November 14, 2017, a Financial Aid/Scholarship Workshop offered focused on Financial Literacy and Scholarship opportunities. Overall, this workshop was rated as excellent or good by 28 PROMISE participants.  T

 

High Impact #2:  Learning Communities

UNIV 101 University Experience Class

PROMISE Scholar are enrolled in UNIV 101, University Experience course during the fall semester.  On November 27, 2017, Dr. Sheela Vemu presented a talk to PROMISE Scholars during their UNIV 101 University Experience class on STEM majors. Dr. Vemu discussed the STEM profession, research, major and graduate study.

Mentoring 

The PROMISE Scholars Program offered a mentoring initiative during the fall semester.  10 mentees participated in the Program.  The average grade point average for the Mentors was 3.2.  PROMISE Mentors assisted their mentees with the following questions and issues:  resumes, internship fair, financial aid, studying, tests, friends/relationships, course selection, switching majors, the Navy, finals, time management, and fraternities,

 

Summer Math College.

22 PROMISE Scholars attended the 2017 Summer Math College. This five-week, pre-college experience offers the opportunity for PROMISE Scholars to enhance their math skills, learn about college, and form networks/connections with NIU staff and students who will be in their PROMISE Cohort in the fall.  82% of the Scholars participating in the Summer Math College passed their Fall semester mathematics course.  The Scholars completed the following fall math courses:  Fundamentals of Mathematics, College Algebra, Trigonometry and Elementary Functions, Introduction to Discrete Mathematics and Calculus II.

Annual PROMISE Advancing STEM Education:  Priming the Pump Conference

 

The annual conference, Advancing STEM Education: Priming the Pump, held on March 3, 2018, focused on metacognition. Dr. Sheela Vemu facilitated a workshop titled, “Learning to Learn Effectively in STEM” for 26 PROMISE Scholars.  The one-day student focused conference highlighted metacognition and self-regulated learning strategies.

Research with Faculty.

During the 2017-2018 academic year, 20 Scholars were engaged in research projects with faculty members. These research opportunities provided the PROMISE Scholars with an undergraduate research experience in a STEM major under the direction of a NIU Faculty member.

Significanat Results:      A total of 36 of the 64 (56%) of the PROMISE Scholars in Cohort I (2012) have graduated from NIU; 21 of the 64 (39%) PROMISE Scholars in Cohort II (2013); 8 of the 58(14%) PROMISE Cohort III (2014) and 5 of the 66 (8%) PROMISE58(14%) PROMISE Cohort III (2014) and 5 of the 66 (8%) PROMISE Scholars in Cohort IV have graduated from NIU for a total of 70 to date.
